urn:contentItem:5WJ7-32G1-JBHT-D4YT-00000-00The Real Danger To America Is China; Google's Sundar Pichai Will Be Testifying Before Congress Next Week; Report: FBI Agents Raided Uranium One Whistleblower's Home; General Motors Announced Worker Layoffs And Factory Closings; Cleveland's WDOK Pulls 'Baby, It's Cold Outside' From Christmas Playlist Amid #Metoo Concerns2018-12-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:34:41ZLexisNexisThe Real Danger To America Is China; Google's Sundar Pichai Will Be Testifying Before Congress Next Week; Report: FBI Agents Raided Uranium One Whistleblower's Home; General Motors Announced Worker Layoffs And Factory Closings; Cleveland's WDOK Pulls 'Baby, It's Cold Outside' From Christmas Playlist Amid #Metoo ConcernsLanhamFULL TEXT

TUCKER CARLSON- HOST: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT. A lot going on, as always.

A new investigation of Google uncovers how employees of the sinister tech monopoly once again discussed ways to censor your political views without your knowledge. Nobody in Congress seems to think this as a problem. These new details might change their minds, fingers crossed.

Plus, yesterday, we told you how Rudolph, the Red-Nosed Reindeer has made the banned list for bullying, and other imaginary moral crimes.

Now, the Victorians have another target, the salacious Christmas song, Baby, It's Cold Outside. It turns out some of the lyrics in that tune are naughty, and you should not be allowed to hear them. The Liberal Sherpa joins us later to explain why.

But first tonight, it's been 752 days since the 2016 election. And for what seems like the 752nd day in a row, the lead story in every news outlet in this country is Russia.

Yes, Russia, a remote country in Central Asia with a median life expectancy lower than that of Honduras. A place with an economy about the size of that of the State of Texas, a vodka-soaked icescape (ph), whose shuffling workforce can't seem to build a reliable airplane, that's Russia.

But nevertheless, it's a place that somehow, against all odds, manages to dictate election outcomes on the other side of the world, using a crack team of Secret Agents, so stealthy, we still don't know their names after more than two years of investigating it. Russia.

According to cable news, Russia is the most important country in the world. Today's installment of the Russia saga has something to do with Michael Cohen and a potential real estate deal in Moscow. Now, the deal never actually happened, not that would have made any difference, had it happened. Foreign investment is still legal, even in Russia, but whatever.

This is a huge, huge deal, the hugest deal. It changes everything forever. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RON INSANA, SENIOR ANALYST & COMMENTATOR, CNBC: This President may not serve out his term that -- that Bob Mueller may have enough that there's both intense legal and intense political jeopardy for the President of the United States.

JEFFREY ROSS TOOBIN, LEGAL ANALYST, CNN AND THE NEW YORKER: You know, today's the first day I actually thought Donald Trump might not finish his term in office.

ANDERSON HAYS COOPER, AUTHOR, PRIMARY ANCHOR, ANDERSON COOPER 360 , CNN: Really?

TOOBIN: I mean I think this thing is enormous.

JOY BEHAR, CO-HOST, THE VIEW: Today is a good day for Donald Trump to resign. I really believe that.

(CROWD CHEERING)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: This thing is enormous. He's resigning. So, once again, the Administration is doomed because of Russia. We'll see.

What's remarkable though is that for the past couple of years, as the geniuses on cable television has -- have been sounding the relentless alarm about our mortal foe, Vladimir Putin, an actual threat to America has been rising in the East.

If you're looking for a country to fret about, forget about Russia. The Russians may pose a threat to Montenegro and Ukraine, but Phoenix and Buffalo remain safe. The real danger to this country is China, and everybody in power knows that.

The FBI Director, Christopher Wray, describes China as by far the biggest espionage threat we face. Federal officials estimate there are thousands of Chinese nationals in America right now, acting as spies, working to steal sensitive U.S. technologies.

Some of these work for the Chinese military, which, by the way, is growing at a much faster rate than our military or, for that matter, Russia's. Meanwhile, China is literally poisoning the American population.

Synthetic opioids are the main driver of the drug epidemic that has killed more than 70,000 Americans in just the last year. China is the biggest source of these drugs. The Chinese government has done virtually nothing to stop the flow of them. Why would they? This is war, and they're winning.

Now, you might think our media would have noticed all of this and maybe written a story or two about it. But, no. Many of them, it turns out, are on the Chinese payroll too.

Vox.com recently published a nauseatingly sycophantic piece written by a reporter who had just traveled to China, it turns out, on the Chinese government's dime.

Over at Jeff Bezos' Washington Post, you'll periodically see an entire insert called China Watch. It looks like a news section. It reads like the rest of the paper.

In fact, it's literally a product of Chinese state media. They paid to place it, just as they paid and influenced numerous think tanks around Washington, as well as many colleges and universities throughout the country. It's a huge propaganda push that is almost never noted by anybody, and it costs a lot. But over time, it's worth it.

The Chinese get what they pay for, a compliant American establishment that uses fake threats, manufactured threats from Russia to obscure real and imminent threats from China. Turns out, there really are traitors in Washington, but they're not working for the Kremlin.

Julian Epstein is a former Chief Counsel for Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee, and he joins us tonight. So, Julian, you and I both live in Washington, and we know personally a lot of people who are in effect on the Chinese payroll.

Madeleine Albright has made a lot of money from China. John Boehner, the former Republican Speaker, works for a firm that lobbies for China. Jim Wolfensohn, who ran the World Bank, advises the Chinese Sovereign Wealth Fund, etcetera, etcetera, etcetera.

How many people do you know who are openly working for Russia in Washington?

JULIAN EPSTEIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST, FORMER CHIEF DEMOCRATIC COUNSEL TO HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: I think your basic point that the Chinese are a greater long-term threat to us than Russia is, I think, that's true. I think in the 1970s, China had about 1 percent of the flows of world trade. They now have about 25 percent.

CARLSON: Right, exactly.

J. EPSTEIN: They have about 2 percent of the global economy. And within the decade, they will be equal to the size of the U.S. economy. By 2050, they will be twice the size of the U.S. economy.

I think we thought, when we brought them into the World Trade Organization in -- in 2001, that it would help them play fair. And I think what we've seen since then is that they've cheated. They've stolen intellectual property.

Up until 2014, they were certainly manipulating the currency. I don't think they play by the rules. And I think one of the things I agree with the President on is to get tough with China. I would approach it differently than he does. But I think he's right to get tough on China.

I think the media ought to focus more on it. It's not as sensational, so it's not going to get good ratings on cable television, but it's a real problem. The disappearing middle class and working class is a real problem.

It's not sensational. It's not going to be a sugar-high for cable television, so you -- I don't think you're going to have any of the networks, not this network, not CNN, not MSNBC, any of them focusing on those issues because you just don't get the sugar-high from that.

That's not to say Russia isn't a threat. I mean Russia has done lots of things. All of our intelligence agencies and Republican and Democratic Administrations have agreed--

CARLSON: Right.

J. EPSTEIN: --that even though they're 1 percent in the world economy, they still do lots of things that are directly oppositional to us, and that are trying to destabilize our interests--

CARLSON: Sure.

J. EPSTEIN: --whether it's in the Middle East, whether it's in Syria, whether it's in the Balkans, whether it's in the U.K. It doesn't mean that they're not a real threat, and there's not something to take seriously.

But I think your basic point is correct, which is that we are sleeping while Rome burns with respect to China, and we have not taken seriously the fact that they don't play by the rules. We have, you know--

CARLSON: Wait, so I'm -- I'm waiting to jump in with a hostile question, but you're making my case for me. You've taken--

J. EPSTEIN: I -- well I -- I agree--

CARLSON: --all of my questions and reformatted them into--

J. EPSTEIN: --I agree with--

CARLSON: --statements because I think you're absolutely right. So -- so, I guess--

J. EPSTEIN: --I agree with the metathesis. I agree with--

CARLSON: --well OK. Because I think--

J. EPSTEIN: --the metathesis.

CARLSON: --it's hard to -- and thank you for being honest about that. And I -- by the way, it's not a partisan thing. There are a ton of Republicans working on behalf of China, I'm embarrassed to say.

J. EPSTEIN: And Democrats are finally waking up, I think, that there is a real threat that China does not play by the rules, and that it's something to take very seriously. Again--

CARLSON: So, so, so but I wonder though--

J. EPSTEIN: --I would approach it differently than the President. But--

CARLSON: --but--

J. EPSTEIN: --I think he's right to say this is a real problem.

CARLSON: --but there's all this moral outrage about Russia and Saudi Arabia, neither of which I've ever been in favor of, by the way. I'm not carrying water for either one. But the idea that a country we are allied with assassinates one of its political opponents, yes, it's bad.

But, I mean, that is a practically (ph) daily occurrence in China, and no one says anything about it. And I just wonder, should we treat the people in Washington, who have a lot of power, who are getting rich from China, should we treat them as traitors in the same way that we treat anyone who deals with Russia as a traitor?

J. EPSTEIN: I -- look, I think your point about even-handedness is well- taken. I think the Chinese do horrible things to journalists and to dissidents and they -- and they get a pass on it.

I think, in a lot of cases, the social media giants, Facebook and Google, enable a lot of the bad behavior that's going on in a lot of autocratic regimes. We don't hear that much about it although that's starting to get covered.

I think if your point is proportionality, it -- does the news, and particularly cable news, does it cover these things in the proper proportionality? I agree with that meta-point that you're making.

It doesn't mean to say that when the Saudis go and kill an American journalist, we shouldn't be getting tough on the Saudis. It doesn't mean to say if the Russians create a military intelligence attack on the United States that that's not something we shouldn't--

CARLSON: No, and I'm not arguing that.

J. EPSTEIN: --take seriously and we shouldn't -- and we should get to the bottom of that. But I think your basic point is that, you know, there is selective outrage. There is a lot of chest-thumping.

There is a lot of kind of, you know, morally superior indignation that -- that occurs on the Russia issue. And, you know, I -- you and I may have slightly different views on the Russian issue--

CARLSON: I'm trying to argue with you, Julian Epstein--

J. EPSTEIN: --but--

CARLSON: --but it's -- it's proving absolutely impossible.

J. EPSTEIN: --but -- but--

CARLSON: You did a better job than I could have--

J. EPSTEIN: --but, you know--

CARLSON: --in making that case.

J. EPSTEIN: --there -- there's lot of self-righteousness--

CARLSON: Yes, tell me about it.

J. EPSTEIN: --on certain issues. And I -- I think there's reason to be upset about what happened with Russia. There's reason to be upset with Saudi Arabia. But I think if you're going to be outraged on those issues, your point is correct that you should be equally outraged--

CARLSON: Yes.

J. EPSTEIN: --on the abuses--

CARLSON: All right (ph). And -- and that's it--

J. EPSTEIN: --that are occurring--

CARLSON: --right there.

J. EPSTEIN: --in China. And the accusers (ph) in -- in China are very, very serious, and you're exactly right about that.

CARLSON: Julian Epstein, thank you very much.

J. EPSTEIN: OK. Thanks.

CARLSON: Unexpected. Appreciate it.

J. EPSTEIN: Good to see you, Tucker. OK.

CARLSON: Gordon Chang has been thinking about these questions for a very long time. He's the Author of The Coming Collapse of China, and he joins us. So, Gordon, thanks very much for coming on.

Put this into perspective, if you would. To what extent, do you think, the Chinese government influences American policy?

GORDON GUTHRIE CHANG, COLUMNIST, BLOGGER, TELEVISION PUNDIT, LAWYER, THE COMING COLLAPSE OF CHINA AUTHOR: Oh, certainly across the board. We saw it during this midterm elections, the Chinese tried to influence outcomes.

And they did it with not only that famous Des Moines Register's four-page insert. But they also summoned the heads of Wall Street firms to Beijing for that September 16th meeting. You go on and on about the types of things that they've been doing.

CARLSON: Let -- let me -- let me -- let me pause there for our viewers who don't know what you're referring to. September 16th, they, as you put it, summoned the Heads of Wall Street firms to Beijing to do what?

CHANG: To talk about the midterm elections, to talk about tariffs, to talk about the trade relationship because Beijing was very, very concerned about what the Trump Administration is doing to impose costs on China, because it is causing problems in the Chinese economy, which is under stress.

So, they said, "Look, we're holding this meeting. We want you there." And a lot of people from Wall Street actually took the flight to Beijing.

CARLSON: American citizens--

CHANG: American citizens.

CARLSON: --summoned by the Communist Chinese government actually went?

CHANG: They actually went and they held that meeting. And, you know, this shows the power of Beijing, and it shows that they were trying to change the results in the election.

Now, I don't think that it would -- had any real effect. And the reason is, as Julian and you have talked about, across the American political spectrum right now, people are starting to understand the fundamental nature of the challenge that China poses to us.

And it's certainly much greater challenge than Russia, because Russia couldn't challenge the U.S., if it weren't for being backstopped by the Chinese.

CARLSON: Right. So, I mean you've got to think of Russia as sort of a -- a drunk troublemaker that can kind of, you know, make some prank calls. But in the end, China's economy is about to become, as Julian just noted correctly, larger than ours. So, like, why aren't we completely freaked out about our future about this (ph)?

CHANG: Well we should be because the Chinese are taking hundreds of billions of dollars of U.S. intellectual property each year by theft or by force transfer. And -- and that is the lifeblood of our economy because we have an innovation-based economy.

And if we can't commercialize our technology, we don't have an economy. We end up just selling agricultural products to the world and maybe scrap metal.

The point is though we need to have the technological giants that will dominate the future of the world's economy. They should be American. And China, by means which are certainly not fair, is trying to do that.

And one other thing, Tucker, you mentioned Fentanyl and opioid crisis. You know, the Chinese government runs a police state. They know about these Chinese gangs that are selling Fentanyl into the U.S.

CARLSON: Right.

CHANG: And so, those gangs couldn't operate unless they had Beijing's approval. Now, officials on China are making money from it and, in other cases, the Chinese officials are just standing back. But they purposely want to see Americans die. And we can't forget that.

CARLSON: Tens of thousands of Americans do die every year because of synthetic opioids manufactured in China. And yet, I can't remember the last time I heard someone in our political class say that out loud. Why?

CHANG: Well I -- I think that is because there's -- there's a lot of reasons.

Part of it is because a lot of people are actually getting money from China. A number of reasons for other people is that they sort of believe that we should be engaging the Chinese, you know, this is the Nixon policy of trying to work with Beijing, so that it's not on the outside of the international system.

And that sounds nice but it hasn't worked over four decades. We've tried all sorts of things, and -- and it hasn't worked. We've tried negotiation, engagement. We did all those things. And, unfortunately, the Chinese behavior in the economy and in other things has just gotten worse.

CARLSON: Gordon Chang, thank you very much for that.

CHANG: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: Great to see you.

Well employees at Google just got caught, once again, plotting to suppress political views they don't like. We have details on that, after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TEXT: TECH TYRANNY.

CARLSON: More evidence that the sinister tech monopoly, Google, is not on the level, not at all what it claims to be. New leaked communications from inside that company show that Google employees discussed suppressing Conservative news websites in their search engine right after the 2016 election.

In one post from November 9th, 2016, a Google Engineer, called Scott Byer, called The Daily Caller and Breitbart, "opinion blogs," and said that Google employees should reduce the visibility of both sites in search results compared to, "Legitimate news organizations." Other employees said it was the company's job to provide more "Context" to rebut news outlets they dislike.

Robert Epstein is a Senior Research Psychologist at the American Institute for Behavioral Research and Technology, and one of the people who's paid closest attention to the power that Google has. Mr. Epstein, thanks very much for coming on tonight.

So, Google has said repeatedly that it does not manipulate search results. And yet, this is not the first, not even close to the first piece of evidence we have from within the company showing Google employees discussing ways to manipulate search results. Can we be confident they're not doing it?

ROBERT EPSTEIN, SENIOR RESEARCH PSYCHOLOGIST, AMERICAN INSTITUTE FOR BEHAVIORAL RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY, PROFESSOR, AUTHOR, JOURNALIST: Not at all. You know, Google is extremely good at keeping its secrets for almost 20 years. But, in the last few months, that has changed, and there have been quite a number of leaks.

And we have seen a number of internal discussions there like the one that you just described. And there's simply no question that they have very strong political leanings. 95 percent of donations there go to Democrats.

I myself am not a Conservative. I actually--

CARLSON: Right.

R. EPSTEIN: --I -- I -- I kind of lean toward Google's political views. But it's -- it's frightening to me because of what I study day by day. It's frightening to me that this company, with very strong political leanings, has the power to shift millions of votes, to shift opinions on a massive scale without people knowing that they're doing it and without being accountable to the public.

CARLSON: How can you have a democracy under those circumstances where one privately-held company has the power to manipulate people's behavior without people knowing it?

R. EPSTEIN: Well that's what I'm saying. And that's exactly what's happening here, and the situation gets even worse when -- when these huge tech companies, the two largest being Google and Facebook, when they both have the same political leanings.

So, you know, in that kind of scenario, we're talking about the ability to shift in the midterm elections, I calculated, upwards of 12 million votes with no one having any idea that they're doing this. This is not like fake ads where -- which you can see.

CARLSON: Right.

R. EPSTEIN: This is invisible manipulation. I -- I literally have to invent new names for the techniques they're using because they've never existed before.

CARLSON: So, Google assures us that they're not doing this because they're good people, much better people than we are, for example. How can we know if they're telling the truth? And should we believe them?

R. EPSTEIN: Oh well, they're -- they're sure they're good people. That's part of the problem. They have a kind of Utopian thinking within the company, not just among the employees but, you know, their top executives think like Utopians.

So, there -- there -- believe me, they believe that they are doing good for humanity, good for -- good for the United States by imposing their values, their thinking on the rest of us. The problem is, as I say, that they can do it in ways that have never existed before in human history.

CARLSON: So, I know that -- as you already said, you and I have different political views, probably don't vote for the same people, so you're maybe the person to ask.

How can the United States Congress sit back with evidence that democracy, the core idea of democracy, is being challenged by this company, and not do anything about it?

R. EPSTEIN: Well, the Democrats aren't going to do anything because these companies help them, obviously. The Republicans don't like regulations. So, we have a tough problem here in the U.S.

Now, the Europeans, on the other hand, you know, they -- they see these companies as American, and so, there have been -- they've been much tougher on them.

And I think we're going to see -- we're going to see some pretty drastic actions taken against these companies by the EU in the next few years. And that could change their ability to operate worldwide.

CARLSON: I never thought I'd be waiting for France and Germany to come to our rescue but that's -- that's where we are, unfortunately. Mr. Epstein, thank you very much. It was great, as always.

R. EPSTEIN: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: Harmeet Dhillon is an attorney who has frequently, at cost to herself, stood up to big tech, and she joins us tonight. Harmeet, thank you very much for--

HARMEET DHILLON, AMERICAN LAWYER, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL LAWYERS ASSOCIATION BOARD MEMBER, FORMER VICE CHAIRWOMAN OF THE CALIFORNIA REPUBLICAN PARTY, AND THE NATIONAL COMMITTEEWOMAN OF THE REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE FOR CALIFORNIA: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: --coming on tonight.

So, this, again, as I just heard (ph) Mr. Epstein, yet another example of evidence from within this company, and there are other examples like it from Facebook, that show that they're not on the level, that they're lying to us, and that they could undermine the very basis of our democracy.

Let me ask you the same question. Why is Congress standing by in the face of this evidence and doing nothing?

DHILLON: Let me add to that, why is the Department of Justice not opening up anti-trust investigations?

CARLSON: Well, exactly.

DHILLON: Why is the Federal Trade Commission not investigating them for their deceptive trade practices and failure to disclose their manipulation of data and theft of data from Americans and others?

So, today itself, the European Union opened up a new, its fourth in the last two years' investigation into Google for anti-trust issues for manipulating search. Guess what? And so far, they've been fined $7.1 billion in Europe in the last 17 months, but zippo here in the United States on the same issues.

And one of the reasons, Tucker, is that these companies, both of them are very adept at spreading money around Capitol Hill, including through the use of a former Republican Congresswoman, Susan Molinari, and those are their lobbyists, and they're very effective.

That's why you see legislators backing off for the most part. But we are talking about fascistic, you know, control of our data in a way that is perceived as benevolent by -- certainly by Liberals and is not being criticized at all by the Right. I think it's a very dangerous situation.

CARLSON: So, but what's the point? I mean, just as (ph) a macro question, what's the point of having a government, of sending half your income every year to Washington, if they won't protect you from the most basic and obvious threat to our entire system, which is these companies? Why do we have a government if they won't stand up to Google and Facebook?

DHILLON: Well, interestingly, I think we're going to see some action on the part of these companies, against these companies, I should say, in the new Congress because Liberals are concerned about the data theft much more so than Conservatives are.

But we're still not going to see anything about this bias in terms of viewpoint. In addition to what you've covered on your segment tonight so far, obviously, there's suppression of -- of YouTube videos on an ideological basis.

Google also discourages its advertisers from advertising on Conservative platforms like Breitbart and others. Google's search engine has labeled the California Republican Party as having Nazi ideology and Republican Women as -- as being enablers.

It is the most despicable, defamatory work, and it is all protected by the Communications Decency Act, which members of Congress certainly could edit and change, but they don't. And so, I'm very disappointed in our government, our Conservative government, frankly, and Washington on its failure to act on these issues.

CARLSON: So, as you just pointed out, very quickly, these companies operate in the way that they do very profitably because they have a special exemption from the Congress, which could revoke that exemption because they're not platforms. They're media companies. Of course, they're editing.

Can -- name just, if you would, since we're live now, three or four Members of Congress who, you know, might lead the charge against this?

DHILLON: Well, actually I guess, I don't think any Members of Congress currently have identified themselves as being hostile to this. But, you know, Jim Jordan certainly seems to be somebody who's familiar with these issues. Matt Gaetz is another.

I think these guys are sensitive to these issues. But -- and I don't think they're beholden to big tech. You know, maybe they haven't been there long enough to have that sink in yet.

CARLSON: Yes.

DHILLON: But -- but we have -- we have had Senators, Mike Lee, for example, has looked at the anti-trust situation, and then backed off. I'd like to see our Senate newly constituted with more votes take a hard look at this, have some hearings, really put them on the spot.

CARLSON: Yes.

DHILLON: Sundar Pichai is going to be testifying in Congress next week. I have suggested that definitely some hard questions need to be asked. And I know that there are certainly -- there's an intention to ask some hard questions next week so--

CARLSON: I hope that happens.

DHILLON: --we'll see what happens.

CARLSON: Hope they get moving. Harmeet Dhillon, you've been brave on this question. We're -- we're grateful for it. Thank you.

DHILLON: My pleasure, thank you.

CARLSON: Well, a man who says he was trying to blow the whistle on the Uranium One deal, remember that, says the FBI repaid him by raiding his house. That story's after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Well, here's an interesting story you may not have seen. FBI agents raided the home of a Uranium One whistleblower. That's according to a new report by The Daily Caller News Foundation.

A man called Dennis Nathan Cain has turned over documents to the DoJ as well as to the both House and Senate Intel committees. The documents allegedly show that federal officials failed to investigate possible criminal activity involving the Clinton Foundation and the Uranium One deal.

Now, Cain says, the FBI repaid him by sending 16 agents to raid his house for six hours.

Dan Bongino is a former Secret Service Agent, NRATV contributor, and Author of Spygate: The Attempted Sabotage of Donald J. Trump. He joins us tonight. Dan, thanks a lot for coming on. So, this is a remarkable--

DANIEL JOHN BONGINO, FORMER AGENT OF THE UNITED STATES SECRET SERVICE, FORMER NYPD OFFICER, NRATV CONTRIBUTOR, SPYGATE AUTHOR: Sure.

CARLSON: --this is one of those stories I personally don't want to believe could be true that we live in a country where the FBI is used to carry out political grudges. How do you assess this?

BONGINO: Well, Tucker, I don't want to believe that, either. Having been a former Federal Agent myself, this is deeply disturbing. But there's -- there's a -- there's -- is a bifurcated way to look at this right now. And I'll just -- I'll just sum it up like this. This is either really, really bad for the Clintons or really, really bad for the FBI, meaning this. You don't typically raid a whistleblower's house. The whole idea of being a whistleblower is you're providing information voluntarily to assist law enforcement or the government.

Why you would raid the house is puzzling to a lot of people? Some people believe that this could be really bad for the Clintons and be kind of a tying up of the Clinton Foundation case that appears to be being investigated by John Huber right now, the United States attorney.

CARLSON: Yes.

BONGINO: On the other hand, Tucker, listen, the people involved in this Uranium One case, the Rosatom and the 10x (ph) case are all people who are knee-deep in the Spygate saga. That -- that's just a fact. That's not a conspiracy theory. It's just true.

Rod Rosenstein, the Deputy Attorney General, was the prosecuting United States Attorney on the precursor case to Uranium One, that disaster, Bob Mueller was the FBI Director.

So, forgive me for not being willing to give everybody a pass on a suspicious raid on a whistleblower's pass. It's just a matter of fact. I -- I guess I should say it this way. I'm not taking anybody at their word any more, and neither should you, either. We should ask questions on this.

CARLSON: But what's so surprising is who's not asking questions about this. So, for generations, the Left elevated the idea of whistleblowing to -- to -- to a sanctified place. Whistleblowers were protected. They are protected in law, and they're protected because Liberals wanted them protected.

And yet, I haven't heard anybody in the Left complain about the FBI raid on this guy's house. Why is that?

BONGINO: Tucker, listen, the -- the -- the rage at -- at Donald Trump has - - has this -- you have brought this up on your show so many times, it can't be highlighted enough.

The Left, which previously aligned with groups like the American Civil Liberties Union that was actually interested, at one point, no more, apparently, in defending civil liberties has--

CARLSON: Yes.

BONGINO: --completely abandoned that now. They have now flipped the script entirely to actually defending weaponized government.

CARLSON: Exactly.

BONGINO: It is unbelievable the transformation we've seen. There's -- listen, it's not in dispute that there are serious abnormalities in the way the Donald Trump investigation was conducted, the Trump team investigation, and the way the Clinton investigation and the Uranium One investigations were sidelined.

But nobody's even remotely curious on the Left about this. It's really incredible, because, Tucker, as you know with government, some day it turns on you too. Government--

CARLSON: It's exactly right.

BONGINO: --doesn't respect party. It's all about power.

CARLSON: It's unwise. Very unwise.

Dan Bongino, thank you, as always, have a great weekend.

BONGINO: Thanks, Tucker. You too.

CARLSON: Well, as you well know, dozens of U.S. cities have decided they're not going to enforce federal immigration law because they don't feel like it. And that's OK with the Left.

Now, one Police Chief is looking to apply the very same standard to gun control laws. How much support is he going to get? He joins us next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Oh, Merry Christmas from General Motors. The car company just announced plans to lay off 15,000 workers and shut down major factories in the states of Michigan, Maryland, and Ohio.

Now, the cuts are coming despite the fact that General Motors has posted nearly $3 billion in profit just last quarter. Workers at one soon-to-be- closed plant told The Wall Street Journal that they were quote, blindsided by the decision. They didn't know it was coming.

One person who will not be struggling to pay for Christmas presents this year is General Motors CEO, Mary Barra. She made nearly $22 million in the last year. That makes her the industry's highest-paid CEO. Toyota's CEO, by stark comparison, makes less than $4 million a year, even though he runs a far more successful company.

Now, what has Mary Barra done to earn all that money? Well, as CEO, she's laid off thousands of workers. She shut down plants and overseen the recall of tens of millions of defective vehicles.

A few years ago, she was forced to testify to Congress about faulty ignition switches that killed more than a hundred drivers. In modern corporate America, that is considered a deeply successful record. Give that woman a raise. Of course, if GM is serious about cutting cost, there is one obvious solution, fire Mary Barra.

Well, for years, Liberal cities and states have been claiming the right to ignore federal immigration law. Now, one small town Police Chief in Washington State is saying the same principle can be applied to far- reaching gun laws.

A new gun control ordinance in Washington imposes stricter background checks, raises the age for buying a semi-automatic rifle, and allows gun owners to be criminally prosecuted if their firearms are stolen, and then used illegally.

Loren Culp is the Police Chief of Republic, Washington, and says that he wants his town to be a sanctuary from these new gun laws. Some local residents oppose the new measure in Washington. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Opponents say it forces gun owners to secure them in a way that could put them in danger.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I'm concerned that not being able to access my gun when I need it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You're not going to tell the criminal, can you hold on a moment because we have a law that I have to, you know, safe -- safely store it in the garage somewhere and, you know, in a -- and so, can you hold on a moment. I'm going to go take it. And I'm going to defend myself. Then, we'll talk.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You call the police or -- or things go down, it's less than one minute, so those seconds count.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Police Chief Loren Culp joins us tonight by Skype. Chief, thanks very much for coming on. It's good to see you.

LOREN CULP, REPUBLIC, WASHINGTON, POLICE CHIEF: Good evening, Tucker, thanks for having me.

CARLSON: So, is this, in effect, a -- a sanctuary, your town, Republic, Washington, from the gun laws of your state?

CULP: I have suggested an ordinance and recommended it to the City Council. And they're in the process of reviewing that, and doing their due diligence, to see if they want to pass that. But as far as the Police Department goes, we will not be enforcing that.

CARLSON: So, cities that have decided to ignore federal -- federal immigration law have received the applause and support of almost everyone on the American Left. What do you think the response will be if your town passes this ordinance?

CULP: I don't think the same people would be very happy. The thing about it is illegal immigrants aren't covered by the Bill of Rights in the Constitution, and gun owners are.

CARLSON: A very good point. So what do -- what will happen next, do you think? Will the Governor of the State try and force you to enforce the law that you think is unconstitutional?

CULP: Well, I don't know how it could, Tucker, because we live in a Constitutional Republic, contrary to what a lot of people tell us that we live in a democracy. But we have the rule of law in this state and across the United States. And the Constitution is the law of the land.

And everybody knows what the Second Amendment says. A lot of your viewers might not know what the Washington State Constitution says about firearms. But really quickly, it says the right of the individual citizen to bear arms in defense of himself or the State shall not be impaired.

So, that's even more explicit than the Second Amendment. So, I -- I don't know how they can get around that and try to force me to go against my Oath of Office to uphold that.

CARLSON: Interesting. I had no idea your state's Constitution said that. It's -- it sounds like it's being already ignored throughout the State of Washington. So, very quickly, this State law would require gun owners to keep their guns locked up at all times?

CULP: It requires you to keep it locked up because if someone gains access to your gun, say, you're -- you're away from home and someone breaks into your home and steals your gun, goes out and commits a crime with it, you can be charged up to a felony for that person getting your gun and committing a crime with it.

CARLSON: If someone--

CULP: Absolutely ridiculous.

CARLSON: --if someone steals--

CULP: It's like charging--

CARLSON: --your car--

CULP: --charging someone who has her car stolen and the person drives off and goes through a crowd of people.

CARLSON: Huh.

CULP: It -- it's ridiculous.

CARLSON: Well, that is ridiculous. And good for you for fighting back against it. Chief Culp, thank you very much for coming on and explaining that. Appreciate it.

CULP: Tucker, I have a real quick message for you, though.

CARLSON: Yes.

CULP: Ted Nugent (ph) told me to tell you hi.

CARLSON: Always a welcome message especially on a Friday. Thank you. Thank you, Chief. Good to see you.

CULP: Good night, thank you.

CARLSON: Well, there's no war on Christmas. That's like some Right-wing trope that only dumb people believe. Meanwhile, the war on Christmas continues apace. Yesterday, it was Rudolph. Today, it's something else and we'll tell you what it is. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

TEXT: THE LIBERAL SHERPA.

CARLSON: Well, the forces of darkness rung in the holiday season with an attack on Rudolph, the Red-Nose Reindeer. That was at HuffPo. But those attacks have expanded to a more familiar line of attack, the classic holiday song, Baby, It's Cold Outside.

Cleveland Radio Station, WDOK, has dropped that song from its Christmas lineup after a listener called in to complain that it was inappropriate, somehow, in the wake of the #MeToo movement.

How about fat-shaming songs about Santa Claus? Will be -- they be the next to go? Here to explain it, The Liberal Sherpa, Catalina Magazine Founder, Cathy Areu.

Cathy Areu, great to see you tonight.

CATHERINE AREU, FOUNDING PUBLISHER, CATALINA MAGAZINE: Good to see you.

CARLSON: It does seem like a lot of the songs about Santa make reference to his weight in a way that is not very sensitive.

AREU: I don't think he minds. I mean, he's jolly, right?

CARLSON: Yes.

AREU: He's a jolly guy.

CARLSON: Baby, It's Cold Outside. Is that song (ph)--

AREU: Yes.

CARLSON: --we need to give up because of #MeToo?

AREU: Not because of #MeToo. I -- I looked at it and it seems like a few years back, people were commenting that the lyrics--

CARLSON: Yes.

AREU: --if you read those lyrics, it's not a holiday song.

CARLSON: Right.

AREU: It doesn't say holidays, happy holidays, Christmas, anything. It's just cold outside. And an older man is telling a younger woman not to go home to her parents, to stay around, have another drink. And she says, "What's in this drink?"

CARLSON: Yes.

AREU: He says, "Don't worry about it." She said, "I feel kind of funny."

CARLSON: Yes.

AREU: "Let's stick around." So, if you read it--

CARLSON: She's getting roofied.

AREU: --yes, apparently, he slipped something in the drink, and she stays the night.

CARLSON: Do we get to a point where human worth, warmth, and romance, are illegal?

AREU: That's not romance. This is a guy slipping her something and she's spending the night, and she doesn't know what happened.

CARLSON: And yet, for 50 years, she never complained about it. I guess she never knew how perfect (ph) she was.

AREU: She did. She said, "I'm trying to say no, no, no." The song explains it. She's saying, "No," in the song.

CARLSON: When--

AREU: No means no, Tucker.

CARLSON: --when Mommy kisses Santa Claus--

AREU: Yes.

CARLSON: --has consent been given?

AREU: When Mommy kisses Santa? I -- I -- it sounds like Mommy was OK with that. She didn't--

CARLSON: Really? This fat guy--

AREU: --say no, no, no.

CARLSON: --comes down your chimney, shows up in your living room and kisses Mommy, and that's voluntary, you're saying.

AREU: I mean the cheek. Wasn't it on the--

CARLSON: Yes, no, I don't -- I don't. But -- no, I don't--

AREU: --cheek.

CARLSON: --think so.

AREU: Oh, OK, because it's not--

CARLSON: Would Frosty, the Snowperson--

AREU: --specified there (ph).

CARLSON: --be a more inclusive title, do you think?

AREU: I think so, yes. Man, you know, that's--

CARLSON: Does the phrase White Christmas--

AREU: --inappropriate, I mean.

CARLSON: --strike you as racist?

AREU: Snow is white, so it's appropriate.

CARLSON: Yes.

AREU: Yellow snow--

CARLSON: It doesn't seem problematic in the slightest?

AREU: I don't think so. I mean--

CARLSON: When White people sing Feliz Navidad, is that cultural appropriation?

AREU: It depends, right? If they sing it with a sombrero, and they're mocking at the culture then, perhaps, yes--

CARLSON: Right.

AREU: --they've crossed the line.

CARLSON: But if they sing it just humming along--

AREU: And appreciating it. And appreciating the song--

CARLSON: --the sound track at Walmart, that's OK?

AREU: --if they appreciate it.

CARLSON: In what sense would they appreciate it?

AREU: Well, if they truly appreciate the language and the culture and understand Feliz Navidad is Merry Christmas, yes, that's fine.

CARLSON: So, if they only know two words of Spanish, Feliz and Navidad--

AREU: Yes.

CARLSON: --that's enough not to be a cultural appropriator?

AREU: Right, right, yes. Appropriation, it -- it's a fine line. Look, but (ph)--

CARLSON: Rudolph, I got to ask you the last question, and this is dead serious.

AREU: OK.

CARLSON: Do you think that Rudolph, the Red-Nose Reindeer is a victim of bullying?

AREU: Yes. That's the whole tale. He is a victim of bullying.

CARLSON: OK.

AREU: Right.

CARLSON: So, is it -- would you say so corrosive because Rudolph accepts his bullying, he doesn't fight back--

AREU: Right.

CARLSON: --that you would keep it from your kids?

AREU: You would have to talk it over and explain it with the kids. The kids nowadays understand anti-bullying much more than kids when that was first created.

CARLSON: But when it comes on, do you sit your kids down and say, look, Rudolph's about to be bullied.

AREU: A responsible parent--

CARLSON: He seems complicit in his own--

AREU: --would.

CARLSON: --but right is but (ph) right. There's a little--

AREU: A responsible parent would.

CARLSON: --Stockholm syndrome, going on now. He doesn't even know he's bullied.

AREU: Yes.

CARLSON: He's leading the sleigh anyway.

AREU: As, yes, as you -- as you would. You would sit down with the child to explain any bullying story. So, yes, Rudolph now needs an explanation.

CARLSON: Do you think that detracts them from (ph) the childlike joy of Christmas when you explain--

AREU: Absolutely not. No--

CARLSON: --to your kids that Rudolph--

AREU: --it's a little scary, I think, for this generation to see that Rudolph is being bullied. So, with this 2018 generation, you would have to explain why he's being bullied for having a red nose.

CARLSON: Is it a little weird that the generation that's afraid of everything and so easily intimidated spend so much time playing war video games, and looking at pornography? I mean on -- so, on the one hand they seem very kind of hardened--

AREU: I would say--

CARLSON: --and the other hand, they seem incredibly sensitive.

AREU: --I -- I can't imagine that they're doing those things.

CARLSON: Yes, I think they might be.

AREU: I don't think so.

CARLSON: Cathy Areu, great to see you--

AREU: Good to see you.

CARLSON: --as always.

Allie Beth Stuckey is the host of a very popular podcast. She joins us tonight to respond to all this. Does Christmas seem as fun as it used to?

ALLIE BETH STUCKEY, AMERICAN JOURNALIST, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR, RELATABLE PODCAST HOST, CRTV: No, it doesn't. And I was just thinking as you guys were talking, how in the world did I survive my childhood years without my parents sitting me down and talking to me about Rudolph, the Red-Nose Reindeer?

I don't know how any of us survived without all of these Liberal Sherpas and these woke (ph) warriors telling us how we should be offended, and how we're actually oppressed by Christmas movies, I just had no idea.

CARLSON: I wonder why the rest of us play along with this. We're kind of complicit in the destruction of the culture that we grew up in, when we take it seriously, just so in (ph) HuffPo, which is, obviously, a ludicrous website.

But I wonder when they run a piece like this, if the rest of us pay any attention at all, and I'm guilty of this as well, if we're not sort of giving it weight and legitimacy. And, maybe, the best is just to totally ignore it, and celebrate Christmas as we always have, and pretend that these people, these deeply unhappy people, mad at their parents, don't exist.

STUCKEY: I don't know. I think it's good to kind of shake them out of their echo chambers a little bit and just to remind them that everything you're saying is absolutely absurd. This has become kind of like a sardonic sport, I think, on the Left.

It's almost a competition to see who can say the most absurd, the most progressive thing about things that have otherwise been innocuous for -- for decades. So, I do think it's important that Conservatives at least weigh in a little bit and say, "OK, let's talk about this factually."

CARLSON: You don't think that that I mean that they're kind of trolling us in the end? I mean they -- they're -- they're--

STUCKEY: Oh, I -- no, I know (ph).

CARLSON: --trying. I mean I sometimes feel like maybe it's too easy to get a rise out of me, and it's better just to laugh at them--

STUCKEY: No, I think--

CARLSON: --and say, you know, go back to your -- your sad dystopia in Brooklyn and argue amongst yourselves--

STUCKEY: --yes.

CARLSON: --that I'm not participating in this.

STUCKEY: Yes. I see what you're saying, but I don't know. I don't know. I think that we do need to weigh in on these conversations because if we let them slide, they do -- they do slip into the mainstream.

I wish that they were trolling us. This is why it's so hard to parody the Left. It's why it's so hard to have satire of the Left because of the things they say sound like satire. And I do think that we need to call that out for fear that this will become normal.

CARLSON: Huh? Do you think that 10 years from now, people will be free to use the term, snowman?

STUCKEY: Oh, no. It's already snowperson. Haven't you heard? It's--

CARLSON: Is it? Really?

STUCKEY: --gingerbread person. Yes, gingerbread person. Come on, Tucker. You're behind the woke (ph) times.

CARLSON: My Producer just said in my ear, snowfolk. Have you heard of this?

STUCKEY: Snowfolk, I can't even say that. Snowfolk. Snowfolk, I can't say it. I'll have to--

CARLSON: Yes.

STUCKEY: --work on that one.

CARLSON: I'm not playing along. The mailman brings Christmas cards with snowmen on them. That's the world that--

STUCKEY: Oh, man. You're going to get--

CARLSON: --I live in. And I'm not--

STUCKEY: --censored. You might get taken off air.

CARLSON: --changing.

Allie Beth Stuckey, great to see you tonight. Thank you very much.

STUCKEY: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: All right, we've always had a place in our heart and in the lineup of this show for the weird and unexplained, and nothing is changing tonight.

We bring you news of a newly found skeleton that washed up from the sea that raises the question, "What is under the water? What is this thing?" It is science. And we'll bring you the cutting edge, after the break.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(UFO FLYING SOUND)

TEXT: THE TRUTH IS OUT THERE?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(MUSIC)

TEXT: THE TRUTH IS OUT THERE?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Well, a photograph of a skeleton posted recently online has a lot of people asking, what is going on in the depths of the sea.

During a weekend walk on the beach, a New Zealand woman discovered a winged skeleton with spiked skin and a mouth that resembles a creature from the movie, Alien, there it is, the one that eats your guts and then explodes through your chest.

Fear not though. A Marine Ecologist says that the skeleton is not from outer space. It's something called a New Zealand rough skate. It lives mostly about 700 feet below the surface. And, of course, now, it will reside forever in your nightmares. That's our gift to you going into this weekend, which we hope you enjoy intensely.

We'll be back Monday night at 8:00, the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness and groupthink.

Jun 16, 2020( JD Supra: http://www.jdsupra.com Delivered by Newstex) Previously we discussed a Unified Patents' article,[1] the 'FRAND SCAM' fails to address many key points.[2] But worse than these sins of omission, the article goes so far as to make some outlandish misrepresentations about the overturned TCL decision. For example, Unified incorrectly posits that the 'court [] concluded [] that Ericsson had violated its FRAND obligations.' However, the TCL decision actually determined that Ericsson had met its FRAND obligations with respect to its course of conduct. The decision states: 'Ericsson negotiated in good faith and its conduct during the course of negotiations did not violate its FRAND obligation.'

(p3[3]) The article also incorrectly claims that Ericsson agreed with TCL on the number of patents that were actually essential. However, as the TCL decision makes clear, 'Ericsson made numerous challenges to the process that produced these numbers []. Ericsson challenged the results of this process' (p30[4]) Ericsson challenged these numbers because TCL's 'experts' spent only 20 minutes per patent in their analysis, producing a vast over-counting of industry's essential patents to Ericsson's detriment. Indeed, this was the exact criticism that the UK court leveled on this type of exercise. Tellingly, a later study found the results of the 20-minute-per-patent review to be comparable to random guesswork.Rather than correcting for all of those obvious mistakes uncovered by courts and industry analysts, the article propagates them. If Unified Patents wants to rely on bad data, poor analysis, vacated court cases, and blatantly false misstatements to pitch its business, potential clients and businesses need to ask themselves if they can afford to trust what Unified is selling.Even more, egregiously, is the following statement from the Unified article:It does not require much imagination to connect this seeming unfairness [I Ericsson's licensing practices] with the investigation started in 2019 by China's State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) into Ericsson's licensing practices.SAMR, the successor of China's NDRC, SAIC, and MOFCOM agencies[5] is, in fact, investigating Ericsson[6]. As someone who has had the pleasure of being the guest of the thugs at the NDRC[7], ostensibly investigating my former employer's licensing practices[8], I know full well that China's Anti-monopoly law is a weapon to be used against foreigners[9]. Do not just take my word for it, the USTR[10] ('Many U.S. companies have cited selective enforcement of the Anti-monopoly Law against foreign companies seeking to do business in China as a major concern []. U.S. industry has expressed concern about insufficient predictability, fairness, and transparency in Anti-monopoly Law investigative processes'), the White Office[11] of Trade and Manufacturing Policy[12] ('China seeks to force foreign patent and technology holders to accept below-market royalty rates in licensing and other forms of below-market compensation for their technologies'), the US Chamber of Commerce[13] (The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has been forthright in expressing our serious concerns regarding a range of Chinese government policies and practices that restrict access to its market, condition participation in the market on technology transfer, and broadly seek to undermine the value of intellectual property held by American companies. These are global concerns that have also been voiced by stakeholders from around the world over many years'), and many others agree.As if further proof of SAMR's ulterior motive as a weapon of Chinese industrial policy, SAMR is now conducting[14] one of the first, if the not the first, competition law authority investigation, at the behest of a Chinese PAE, Iwncomm, into whether a company (Apple) is an unwilling licensee for engaging in 'hold out' failing to take a license on Iwncomm's FRAND terms. To be clear, SAMR does have a powerful argument to make that Apple is indeed a long time manipulator of the FRAND regime and a classic unwilling licensee - as the opening slides in Qualcomm's FRAND litigation with Apple demonstrate[15].Nevertheless, given one still must wonder why Unified would seemingly be carrying the water for China's antitrust authorities. Perhaps it has something to do with a major Unified backer's long history of giving aid to favored Chinese companies in their use of SAMR against SEP licensors[16].Indeed, after focusing on a reversed court decision, ignoring the two relevant court decisions, failing to grasp industry practice, and deceiving the reader with false statements, the article comes to the elevator pitch, describing Unified Consulting's services:'Using machine learning, Unified Patents has developed its Objective Patent Landscaping (OPAL) algorithm to identify essentiality based on sematic similarities [].'While an AI tool to perform essentiality and validity testing would be of great interest, any such tool is only as good as the algorithms and experts used to train it. To this end, one important prerequisite of any Artificial Intelligence (AI) tool is to be auditable (for more information, see here[17] or here[18] as examples of why AI audits are important). In other words, one needs to be able to determine whether a specific statistic or trait fed into an algorithm is being favored or disadvantaged at a statistically significant, systematic rate, leading to inaccurate results or adverse impacts on those underrepresented in the data set. Otherwise, the foundational rule of all computer science takes over and causes the entire project to be suspect:Garbage In, Garbage Out.[19]Based on the statements from Unified Patents in the article, it is hard not to wonder whether OPAL is a tool jury-rigged for LTE implementers, not for all LTE stakeholders. As such, it is reasonable to suspect that OPAL provides not only inaccurate results for being unfit for purpose but results that are inherently biased towards big tech and implementers. Such concerns will only be resolved when neutral third parties have audited OPAL. Until then two principles apply - caveat emptor (buyer beware) and cui bono (who benefits).Throughout its article, Unified Patents misleads its readers about the current state of the law on FRAND, and fails to offer well-rounded advice that can help customers navigate towards successful patent licensing outcomes. This lack of full candor makes it impossible to substantiate their claims. Could this qualify as unfair and deceptive advertising? Should consumer protection agencies discourage this type of false statement? Regardless, those who blindly follow Unified Patents' sloppy advice will undoubtedly face the consequences in court - up to triple damages for willful patent infringement, or injunctions. And then they'll understand the real scam. urn:contentItem:5PGM-4741-JCPJ-W2KP-00000-00The real motivations behind business, tech vs. Trump on DACA2017-09-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:34:40ZLexisNexisThe real motivations behind business, tech vs. Trump on DACAMike Sunnucks

Immigration can be a divisive issue.

But not for an increasing number of businesses - including some giant technology and social media brands, as well as traditionally Republican-leaning business groups.

Technology and business interests lined up en masse against U.S. President Donald Trump's nixing of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program started by former President Barack Obama in 2012.

DACA supporters ranged from the CEOs of national giants such as Facebook inc.(NYSE: FB), Apple Inc.(Nasdaq: AAPL), Amazon.com Inc.(Nasdaq: AMZN) and Microsoft Corp.(Nasdaq: MSFT) to local business groups such as the Arizona Chamber of Commerce & Industry and Arizona Technology Council.

They argue that doing away with deportation protections for 800,000 DACA immigrants who grew up as Americans would hurt the economy, workforce and tax revenue. Those protected were brought to the U.S. illegally by their parents when they were children, and they now range from their teens to their early 30s.

In ending DACA, Trump sought to force Congress to deal with the issue but he also pledged on Twitter (NYSE: TWTR) to revisit DACA if need be.

The hue and cry regarding Trump and DACA shows not only large portions of the business community are taking more inclusive and progressive stances on immigration, but more big business brands and chambers of commerce are being vocal on issues that cut across cultural and political lines.

Protecting their workforce

Greg Sexton, a public relations executive with Santy, a Scottsdale-based communications firm, said many businesses see it in their best interests to be inclusive. That includes the intersection of immigration and finding skilled workers.

"Many high-tech, manufacturing and industrial sectors rely on immigration as part of a productive workforce, so they're doing it to protect their livelihood," Sexton said. "If we're not going to spend the money we need to improve education and produce world-class professionals, we need to bring in workers from outside our borders."

Peter Madrid, CEO of MadridMedia, a Phoenix-based public relations and marketing firm, said many big U.S. companies and brands are looking to reflect where they operate and appeal not only to a diverse but global marketplace.

"We are a global society, and should conduct business accordingly," Madrid said.

Arizona's population is 31 percent Hispanic, according to the U.S. Census Bureau, and many big companies backing DACA and opposing Trump on immigration are in more diverse and politically liberal regions, such as California, New York and the Pacific Northwest.

"Businesses should reflect the communities in which they exist. We are a nation of immigrants," Madrid said of some of the motivations behind business stances on DACA.

Hiring at someone's expense

Skeptics point out many technology companies opposing Trump on DACA and previous travel bans aimed at several Muslim majority countries are the biggest users of foreign worker visas. Critics of those programs say U.S. companies use them to hire fewer less-expensive and status beholding foreign workers.

Microsoft, Amazon, Google parent Alphabet (Nasdaq: AAPL) and Apple all rank among the most frequent users of foreign worker visa programs, according to MyVisaJobs.com.

Conservatives - including Trump and U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions - also contend more open immigration policies backed by business interests result in more cheap immigrant labor, legal and undocumented, that pushes down wages and takes jobs from U.S. citizens.

Trump is looking to change some foreign worker visa programs to encourage employers to "hire American." On DACA, Sessions and Trump argued its creation via an executive order from Obama stepped on congressional powers.

Madrid said employers see a broader worry in Trump's populist moves on immigration and attracting and keeping skilled workers.

"We're educating a new generation of immigrants who are becoming engineers, doctors, scientists, and yes, journalists, at American colleges, then losing them to their native countries," Madrid said. "We need to make staying in the U.S. more welcoming and appealing to them."

Support without a downside

Sexton said he really doesn't see a downside for companies speaking out on DACA. Part of that dynamic stems from the sympathetic nature of the DACA immigrants. That group, dubbed "Dreamers," was brought into the U.S. at young ages, raised as Americans and many are students or working.

Barrett Marson, CEO of MarsonMedia, a Phoenix-based communications consulting firm, agreed.

"They support the so-called Dreamers because, well, who could be against a dreamer? Isn't that the American Dream?" Marson said.

Glenn Hamer, president and CEO of the Arizona Chamber of Commerce & Industry, is a top ally of Arizona Gov. Doug Ducey, a Republican liked by Trump. But Hamer has been a leading business critic of Trump's DACA decision.

Hamer said the potential deportation of DACA immigrants - including 30,000 in Arizona - will hurt the economy and impede Trump's bid for 3 percent GDP growth.

Marson said for big companies such as Google and Apple, it shows a worldwide and diverse customer base that they are inclusive and compassionate. That can be good for business as the U.S. becomes more diverse and global markets such as China and India become more important.

"And we can't forget the struggle for the legal tender," Marson said. "The people who lead corporations realize they need to sell as many of their products as possible."

Marson points out Corporate America and big tech companies previously were progressive advocates of same-sex marriage.

While business interests support Trump's proposed tax cuts and pullback on Obama administration regulations, they worry about his positions and rhetoric on trade and immigration. DACA offered a chance to challenge that.

"He's shaking things up and making some folks nervous," Madrid said of Trump.

STEVE KROFT: You think Google's a monopoly?

GARY REBACK: Oh, yes. Of course, Google's a monopoly. In fact they're a monopoly in several markets. They're a monopoly in search. They're a monopoly in search advertising.

JONATHAN TAPLIN: They know who you are, where you are, what you just bought, what you might want to buy. And so if I'm an advertiser and I say I want twenty-four-year-old women in Nashville, Tennessee, who drive trucks and drink bourbon, I can do that on Google.

***

ELIZABETH HOLMES: Our work is in being able to make testing more accessible.

NORAH O'DONNELL (voiceover): Elizabeth Holmes was a charismatic Stanford dropout, who promised to revolutionize blood testing, by using this small box, supposedly filled with dazzling technology. The invention was backed by hundreds of millions of dollars from A-list investors, until the Theranos story unraveled.

JOHN CARREYROU: This is one of the most epic failures in corporate governance in the annals of American capitalism.

***

TRISH NELSON: He would ask to wrestle with me. He would try to grab me. He's a monster.

ANDERSON COOPER: Really? A monster?

TRISH NELSON: I think Mario Batali's a monster.

ANDERSON COOPER (voiceover): Trish Nelson was a waitress in a New York restaurant called The Spotted Pig, where she often served, and she says was abused, by celebrity chef Mario Batali. She and several other women are speaking out tonight because the sexual abuse they experienced is all too common, they say, in the restaurant business.

JAMIE SEET: He crossed a line, a huge, a huge line--assaulting someone that's unconscious.

***

STEVE KROFT: I'm Steve Kroft.

LESLEY STAHL: I'm Lesley Stahl.

SCOTT PELLEY: I'm Scott Pelley.

ANDERSON COOPER: I'm Anderson Cooper.

NORAH O'DONNELL: I'm Norah O'Donnell.

BILL WHITAKER: I'm Bill Whitaker. Those stories tonight on 60 MINUTES.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

THE REAL POWER OF GOOGLE

STEVE KROFT: This past week, the Federal Trade Commission was asked to investigate the data collected by Google on its Android operating system, which powers most of the world's smartphones. It was a tiny blip in the news cycle but another sign of Washington's and Europe's growing concerns about the enormous, largely unchecked power accumulated by tech giants like Facebook, Amazon and Google over the last two decades. Of the three, Google, which is part of a holding company called Alphabet, is the most powerful, intriguing, and omnipresent in our lives. This is how it came to be.

(Begin VT)

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Most people love Google. It's changed our world, insinuated itself in our lives, made itself indispensable. You probably don't even have to type Google.com into your computer, it's often the default setting, a competitive advantage Google paid billions of dollars for. No worry. Google is worth more than three-quarters of a trillion dollars right now and you don't get that big by accident. Since going public in 2004, Google has acquired more than two hundred companies, expanding its reach across the internet. It bought YouTube, the biggest video platform. It bought Android, the operating system that runs eighty percent of the world's smartphones. And it bought DoubleClick, which distributes much of the world's digital advertising, all of this barely raising an eyebrow with regulators in Washington.

Were any of those acquisitions questioned by the antitrust division of the Justice Department?

GARY REBACK: Some were investigated, but only superficially. The government just really isn't enforcing our antitrust laws. And that's what's happened. None of these acquisitions have been challenged.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Gary Reback is one of the most prominent antitrust lawyers in the country widely credited with persuading the Justice Department to sue Microsoft back in the nineties, the last major antitrust case against big tech. Now he is battling Google.

You think Google's a monopoly?

GARY REBACK: Oh, yes. Of course Google's a monopoly. In fact they're a monopoly in several markets. They're a monopoly in search. They're a monopoly in search advertising.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Those technologies are less than twenty-five years old, and may seemed small compared to the industrial monopolies like railroads and standard oil a century ago. But Reback says there's nothing small about Google.

GARY REBACK: Google makes the internet work. The internet would not be accessible to us without a search engine

STEVE KROFT: And they control it.

GARY REBACK: They control access to it. That's the important part. Google is the gatekeeper for-- for the World Wide Web, for the internet as we know it. It is every bit as important today as petroleum was when John D. Rockefeller was monopolizing that.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Last year, Google conducted ninety percent of the world's internet searches. When billions of people asked trillions of questions, it was Google that provided the answers, using computer algorithms known only to Google.

JONATHAN TAPLIN: They have this phrase they use "competition is just a click away." They have no competition. Bing, their competition, has two percent of the market. They have ninety percent.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Jonathan Taplin is a digital media expert and director emeritus of the Annenberg Innovation Lab at the University of Southern California. He says Google's expertise may be technology, but its business is advertising. And its most valuable commodity is highly- specialized information about us. It's helped Google control roughly sixty percent of worldwide advertising revenue on the internet. Taplin says traditional companies can't compete because they don't have the data.

JONATHAN TAPLIN: They know who you are, where you are, what you just bought, what you might want to buy. And so if I'm an advertiser and I say I want twenty-four-year-old women in Nashville, Tennessee who drive trucks and drink bourbon, I can do that on Google.

GARY REBACK: People tell their search engines things they wouldn't even tell their wives. I mean, it's a very powerful and yet very intimate technology. And that gives the company that controls it a mind-boggling degree of control over our entire society.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Google is so dominant in search and search advertising that analysts and venture capitalists in Silicon Valley say it's extremely difficult for startups to get funding if their business model requires them to compete with Google for ad revenue. Jeremy Stoppelman co-founded Yelp more than a decade ago--a website that collects local reviews on everything from auto mechanics to restaurants nationwide and makes money selling ads.

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: The initial promise of Google was to organize the world's information. And ultimately that manifested itself in you expecting that the top links, the things that it shows at the top of that page are the best from around the web, the best that the world has to offer. And I could tell you that is not the case. That is not the case anymore.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Instead of doing what's best for consumers, Stoppelman says Google is doing what's best for Google.

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: If I were starting out today, I would have no shot of building Yelp. That opportunity has been closed off by Google and their approach.

STEVE KROFT: In what way?

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: Because if you provide great content in one of these categories that is lucrative to Google, and seen as potentially threatening, they will snuff you out.

STEVE KROFT: What do you mean snuff you out?

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: They will make you disappear. They will bury you.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Yelp and countless other sites depend on Google to bring them web traffic--eyeballs for their advertisers. But now Stoppelman says their biggest competitor in the most lucrative markets is Google. He says it's collecting and bundling its own information on things like shopping and travel and putting it at the very top of the search results, regardless of whether it belongs there on merit.

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: So let's start off with sushi--

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): He showed us how it worked by Googling sushi San Francisco.

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: All the prime real estate is here. This is where the consumer, their eye focuses. And that's by design; Google wants you to pay attention to their content.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): All of the information here is owned by Google from the maps to the reviews. Stoppelman says if you click on any of these links at the top of the page, you may think you've gone to another website but in fact you will still be on Google, seeing what it wants you to see while it collects your personal information and maybe exposes you to Google advertising.

If you click anything inside this box, you stay on Google and they make more money?

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: That's right.

STEVE KROFT (voiceover): Google told us it doesn't have anything to do with money. It's about improving its product by making searches quicker and easier for its customers by eliminating the need to click through lots of other sites. Stoppelman says it's about stifling competition, pushing it down the page where it's less likely to be seen. The advantage, he says, is even more striking if you look at the search results on a smartphone.

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: This is exactly what your phone would look like in the palm of your hand. This is all of Google's own property, right here. It takes up the entire screen.

STEVE KROFT: How important is that first page?

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: It's not even just the first page. It's the first few links on the page is the vast majority of where user attention goes, and where the traffic flows.

STEVE KROFT: They closed the case?

GARY REBACK: They closed the case, correct.

GARY REBACK: They have a seat at the table in every discussion that-- that implicates this issue at all. They know about developments that we never even hear about. So their influence from my perspective is very, very difficult to challenge.

Last summer she levied a record 2.7 billion dollar fine against Google for depriving certain competitors of a chance to compete with them.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Just as well as I admire some of the innovation by Google over the last decade-- well, I want their illegal behavior to stop.

STEVE KROFT: And that's what you feel has gone on.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Not only do we feel it, we-- we mean that we can prove it.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: It's very difficult to find the rivals. Because on average, you'd find them only on page four in your search results.

STEVE KROFT: And why so far down?

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Well, because then you don't find them. I don't-- I don't know anyone who goes to page four in their search result. The-- jokingly, you could say that this is where you should keep your secrets. Because no one ever comes there.

STEVE KROFT: Do you think this has been deliberate on Google's part?

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Yes. We think that this is done on purpose.

STEVE KROFT: How do they do it? I mean, I think everybody has this idea that Google has this algorithm, and they put the best searches right at the top.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER: Well, it is exactly the algorithm that does it--both the-- the promotion of Google themselves and the demotion of others.

If you're in business, you have to be on Google.

GARY REBACK: Google makes the internet work. The internet would not be accessible to us without a search engine

STEVE KROFT: And they control it.

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: They will make you disappear. They will bury you.

JEREMY STOPPELMAN: That`s right.
